"@YungTseTech @nokusu @qcmeetsworld @firefox @github I never understood those comments, I don't know _why_ timestamps would be bad for that (assuming you don't have transaction IDs or something monotonic). So it just came off as a non-sequitor."

"@YungTseTech @nokusu @qcmeetsworld @firefox @github I can't find it now, but I remember being referred to as "old guard".  I was amused that I was insulted for telling young-wipper-snappers that they made a mistake, and were doubling-down on the mistake."

"@YungTseTech @nokusu @qcmeetsworld @firefox @github But my local repo and your local repo are on different filesystems. The mtime is updated when my editor or VCS writes the file. I can even check out last month's code, it'll get the timestamp for now and the build will work."

"@YungTseTech @nokusu @qcmeetsworld @firefox @github If we did share a filesystems, like with NFS it s still works provided our clocks are in sync. Timestamps are usually stored in UTC so timezones don't matter."

"@LogtalkDotOrg @YungTseTech @AnnieTheObscure @nokusu @qcmeetsworld @firefox @github This is what bitbucket does.  In your repo's creation page and I suppose settings you can choose the langauge.  AFAIK they don't do detection."

"@AnnieTheObscure @YungTseTech @LogtalkDotOrg @nokusu @qcmeetsworld @firefox @github And this is pretty important to us niche language people that would love to know if our work gets used _at all_, not the difference between 59 and 60% world dominance."

"@Art_Sempai @firefox For the security, if nothing else. Firefox is much more secure since replacing the old extension API with the new extension API."

"@Art_Sempai @firefox Unfortunately it was not possible to sandbox the legacy extension API. The API was literally "do anything you want to Firefox up to and including replace the entire program." It was open ended integration that was powerful but also impossible to secure."

"@Art_Sempai @firefox And the new API continues to expand in a predictable and secure way so things that are not possible today may be possible tomorrow. It will never be as open ended as the old API but it will be sufficient to replace the overwhelming majority of use cases with security in mind."

"@firefox By default that is how it behaves, but it could be great to somehow know when going to a new container is about to happen in order to keep the current tab, because not always we are aware that the links we click are going to open a containerized tab/session."

"@LencsikeD @firefox Just to be extra sure, are you running the absolute latest version of JAWS 2018? i.e. JAWS check for updates says there aren't any?"

"@LencsikeD @firefox Newer versions of Firefox switched to a multi-process architecture which improves security and performance. Unfortunately, like many major software changes, this required some changes in JAWS. Older versions don't get such updates."

"@LencsikeD @firefox There were several fixes in the April and May updates of JAWS 2018 for Firefox, including some crashes. I'm reasonably sure the crash report you posted is one of the crashes that was fixed."

"@LencsikeD @firefox While the need for users to update is regrettable, especially given that this update is not free, there's little we can do about it. As I noted, changes in software architecture sometimes require screen reader updates, and Jaws updates costing is out of our control."
"@LencsikeD @firefox Yes, we need to fix that notification to remove the ESR bit, since ESR no longer works. Apologies for the oversight."

"@LencsikeD @firefox I meant fix the notification. We can't fix Firefox to work with earlier versions of JAWS. As I noted earlier, the architectural changes  in Firefox required some changes in JAWS, and JAWS only made those changes available for JAWS 2018 users."

"@RandomFFUser @BillStewart415 @mozilla @firefox How would I enforce an Enterprise only FF policy? The non Enterprise FF with it's built in DNS would still work and would still bypass my firewall. Are you victim shaming here? Shall I tell you how I was dressed when the attack began?"

"@BillStewart415 @RandomFFUser @mozilla @firefox you're almost there. an enterprise FW will be _transparent by design_ to FF's new CF-based DNS. so any BYOD is now a mole in my network, an outpost for bad guys. what i will have to do is blackhole CF itself, or at least, the parts that want to serve DNS behind my FW. 1/2"

"@BillStewart415 @RandomFFUser @mozilla @firefox which again begs the question: why is mozilla going to war against me? the DNS is part of the internet's control plane. i will NOT NOT NOT outsource it.
